choices.text: MYC translocation with BCL2 or BCL6 rearrangement
BCL2 translocation with BCL6 rearrangement

questions.text: Which genetic abnormality defines double-hit lymphoma (DHL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MYC translocation with BCL2 or BCL6 rearrangement

 

Option B:

 

DHL is characterized by a combination of MYC translocation (usually t(8;14)) and a rearrangement of either BCL2 (t(14;18)) or BCL6. This results in the overexpression of multiple oncogenes, leading to aggressive lymphoma behavior.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. t(14;18) with MYC overexpression: While t(14;18) is associated with BCL2 overexpression and is seen in follicular lymphoma, it alone does not define DHL. DHL requires the additional presence of a MYC translocation.

 

Option C. BCL2 translocation with BCL6 rearrangement: This combination of rearrangements is not characteristic of DHL. DHL specifically requires a MYC translocation.

 

Option D. Trisomy 12 with BCL6 rearrangement: Trisomy 12 is associated with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), and while BCL6 rearrangement can occur in various lymphomas, this combination does not define DHL.

 

Educational objective:

 

The combined dysregulation of MYC and BCL2/BCL6 is the defining feature of DHL.

choices.text: R-CHOP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Prednisone)
HyperCVAD (Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Doxorubicin, Dexamethasone alternating with Methotrexate and Cytarabine)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a standard treatment option for mantle cell lymphoma (MCL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ABVD (Adriamycin, Bleomycin, Vinblastine, Dacarbazine)

 

Option D:

 

ABVD is a standard regimen for Hodgkin lymphoma but not typically used for MCL. R-CHOP, BR, and HyperCVAD are among the treatment options for MCL.

 

Educational objective:

 

Treatment for MCL involves different regimens than those used for Hodgkin lymphoma.

choices.text: R-CHOP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Prednisone)
HyperCVAD (Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Doxorubicin, Dexamethasone alternating with Methotrexate and Cytarabine)

questions.text: Which of the following chemotherapy regimens is NOT typically used as a first-line treatment for symptomatic follicular lymphoma (FL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HyperCVAD (Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Doxorubicin, Dexamethasone alternating with Methotrexate and Cytarabine)

 

Option D:

 

HyperCVAD is a more intensive regimen typically used for aggressive lymphomas. R-CHOP, R-CVP, and BR are more common first-line options for FL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. R-CHOP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Prednisone): This is a widely used and effective first-line treatment for FL. It combines the monoclonal antibody rituximab with a standard chemotherapy regimen (cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone).

 

Option B. R-CVP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Prednisone): This is another commonly used first-line regimen for FL, particularly in older or less fit patients. It is similar to R-CHOP but uses vincristine instead of doxorubicin, which is associated with less cardiotoxicity.

 

Option C. Bendamustine-rituximab (BR): This is a well-tolerated and effective regimen that has gained popularity as a first-line treatment for FL, especially in patients who may not tolerate the anthracycline component of R-CHOP.

 

Educational objective:

 

FL is typically treated with less intensive chemotherapy regimens compared to aggressive lymphomas.

choices.text: Positive tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain
Increased serum uric acid levels

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings is characteristic of hairy cell leukemia (HCL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Positive tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain

 

Option A:

 

The TRAP stain is a classic cytochemical test that is positive in hairy cells of HCL. The other options are not characteristic of HCL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Positive myeloperoxidase (MPO) stain: MPO is an enzyme found in myeloid cells (neutrophils, eosinophils, and monocytes) and is used to diagnose myeloid leukemias. It is not typically positive in HCL.

 

Option C. Increased serum uric acid levels: While elevated uric acid levels can be seen in various hematologic malignancies due to increased cell turnover, it is not a specific finding for HCL.

 

Option D. BCR-ABL1 fusion gene: This genetic abnormality is the hallmark of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and is not associated with HCL.

 

Educational objective:

 

A positive TRAP stain is a useful diagnostic clue for hairy cell leukemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is a potential adverse effect of venetoclax, a BCL2 inhibitor used in CLL/SLL treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor lysis syndrome

 

Option A:

 

Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is a serious complication of rapid tumor cell breakdown and can occur with venetoclax therapy. The other options are not typical adverse effects of venetoclax.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Atrial fibrillation: While cardiac arrhythmias can be a side effect of some cancer therapies, atrial fibrillation is not a common side effect specifically associated with venetoclax.

 

Option C. Diarrhea: Diarrhea is a common side effect of many chemotherapies but is not a characteristic side effect of venetoclax.

 

Option D. Peripheral neuropathy: Peripheral neuropathy (damage to peripheral nerves causing numbness, tingling, or pain) can be a side effect of certain chemotherapy agents, but it is not typically associated with venetoclax.

 

Educational objective:

 

Monitoring for and preventing TLS is crucial when initiating venetoclax therapy in CLL/SLL.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic abnormalities is associated with a poor prognosis in CLL/SLL?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Del(17p)

 

Option B:

 

Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 17 (del(17p)) leads to loss of the TP53 tumor suppressor gene, resulting in resistance to chemotherapy and a poorer prognosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Del(13q): This is the most common genetic abnormality in CLL/SLL and is associated with a favorable prognosis. It typically involves deletion of the microRNA genes miR-15a and miR-16-1, which regulate B-cell survival.

 

Option C. Mutated IgVH genes: CLL/SLL cases with mutated IgVH genes generally have a more indolent course and better prognosis compared to those with unmutated IgVH genes.

 

Option D. Trisomy 12: This is an intermediate-risk genetic abnormality in CLL/SLL, with a prognosis between that of del(13q) and del(17p). It can be associated with atypical morphology and increased proliferative activity.

 

Educational objective:

 

del(17p) is a high-risk genetic abnormality in CLL/SLL.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with generalized erythroderma (redness of the skin), intense pruritus, and lymphadenopathy. Peripheral blood smear reveals atypical lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sézary syndrome (SS)

 

Option D:

 

The combination of erythroderma, pruritus, lymphadenopathy, and atypical lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei in the blood strongly suggests Sézary syndrome (SS), a leukemic variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atopic dermatitis: While atopic dermatitis can cause itchy skin, it usually presents with localized patches of dry, scaly skin and does not typically cause erythroderma or lymphadenopathy. It also doesn't have the characteristic cerebriform nuclei seen in SS.

 

Option B. Psoriasis: Psoriasis can also cause itchy, scaly skin, but the plaques are usually well-demarcated and silvery. It does not typically progress to erythroderma or involve lymph nodes. Again, the cerebriform nuclei are not a feature of psoriasis.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides (MF): MF is another type of CTCL and can share some skin features with SS. However, it usually progresses more slowly and doesn't always present with erythroderma. In the early stages of MF, the atypical lymphocytes are typically confined to the skin, not circulating in the blood.

 

Educational objective:

 

SS is characterized by erythroderma, circulating Sézary cells, and lymphadenopathy.

choices.text: Peripheral T-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified (PTCL-NOS)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of breast implants presents with a rapidly enlarging axillary lymph node. Excisional biopsy reveals large atypical cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and abundant cytoplasm. Immunohistochemical staining shows strong expression of CD30. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL)

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation (breast implants, rapidly enlarging lymph node), morphology (large atypical cells, horseshoe-shaped nuclei), and CD30 expression are characteristic of ALCL. While CD30 is also expressed in HL, the morphology of RS cells is different.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hodgkin lymphoma (HL): While HL can express CD30, it lacks the characteristic hallmark cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei seen in ALCL. RS cells are usually larger and have a bilobed or multi-lobed nucleus.

 

Option B. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL): DLBCL is a B-cell lymphoma and would not express CD30. The cells in DLBCL are also not typically described as having horseshoe-shaped nuclei.

 

Option D. Peripheral T-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified (PTCL-NOS): PTCL-NOS is a heterogeneous group of T-cell lymphomas. While it can share some features with ALCL, it does not have the specific hallmark cells or the same association with breast implants.

 

Educational objective:

 

ALCL is a T-cell lymphoma characterized by large atypical cells, CD30 expression, and potential association with breast implants.

choices.text: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with fatigue, bone pain, and elevated serum creatinine. Serum protein electrophoresis reveals an M-spike, and bone marrow biopsy shows 30% plasma cells. Skeletal survey reveals multiple lytic lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiple myeloma (MM)

 

The presence of bone pain, elevated creatinine (indicating renal insufficiency), lytic bone lesions, and >10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow are consistent with multiple myeloma. This fulfills the CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, Bone lesions) necessary for a diagnosis of MM.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS): MGUS is a benign condition characterized by a small M-spike and low levels of plasma cells in the bone marrow (<10%). Crucially, MGUS patients do not have end-organ damage (CRAB criteria).

 

Option B. Smoldering multiple myeloma (SMM): SMM is an intermediate stage between MGUS and multiple myeloma. While it has a higher risk of progression to myeloma, SMM patients typically lack the CRAB criteria that define multiple myeloma.

 

Option D. Waldenström's macroglobulinemia (WM): WM is a type of lymphoma characterized by the overproduction of IgM antibodies. While it can share some features with multiple myeloma (like an M-spike), the clinical presentation and bone marrow findings are different. WM typically does not cause lytic bone lesions.

 

Educational objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by the presence of CRAB criteria, which distinguish it from MGUS and SMM.

choices.text: The patient has standard-risk myeloma and a good prognosis.
The patient has high-risk myeloma and a poor prognosis.
The t(14;16) translocation is not a significant prognostic factor in multiple myeloma.
The patient requires immediate allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

questions.text: A patient with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma has a bone marrow biopsy revealing a t(14;16) translocation. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient's prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The patient has high-risk myeloma and a poor prognosis.

 

Option B:

 

The t(14;16) translocation is a high-risk cytogenetic abnormality in multiple myeloma, associated with aggressive disease and a shorter survival. High risk features: t(4;14), t(14;16), t(14;20), del17p13, +1q, LDH ≥ 2x, PCL

 

Educational objective:

 

Identifying high-risk cytogenetic features in multiple myeloma is crucial for risk stratification and treatment decisions.

choices.text: Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance (MGUS)

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight loss, and blurred vision. Laboratory findings show elevated IgM levels and anemia. Bone marrow biopsy reveals lymphoid cells with plasmacytic differentiation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Waldenström Macroglobulinemia (WM)

 

Option B:

 

The patient's age, symptoms of hyperviscosity (blurred vision), elevated IgM, and bone marrow findings are highly suggestive of WM. MM is less likely due to the absence of lytic lesions and hypercalcemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multiple Myeloma (MM): While MM can cause fatigue, weight loss, and anemia, it is less likely in this case due to the absence of lytic bone lesions (holes in the bones) and hypercalcemia (high calcium levels). MM also typically presents with elevated IgG or IgA, not IgM.

 

Option C. Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance (MGUS): MGUS is a benign condition where a small amount of monoclonal protein is present in the blood. It usually doesn't cause symptoms and wouldn't explain the patient's fatigue, weight loss, blurred vision, or anemia.

 

Option D. Smoldering Multiple Myeloma (SMM): SMM is a precursor to multiple myeloma. While it shares some similarities with MM, it typically doesn't cause symptoms or organ damage. This patient's presentation with fatigue, weight loss, and blurred vision suggests a more active disease process than SMM.

 

Educational objective:

 

WM often presents with hyperviscosity symptoms and bone marrow infiltration by lymphoplasmacytic cells.

questions.text: A patient undergoing allogeneic stem cell transplantation (allo-SCT) develops a maculopapular rash, diarrhea, and elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)

 

Option A:

 

The triad of skin rash, diarrhea, and elevated liver enzymes is characteristic of acute GVHD, a common complication of allo-SCT.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Chronic graft-versus-host disease (GVHD): While chronic GVHD can also affect the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and liver, it typically develops later after transplantation (months to years), and presents with different manifestations like skin thickening, dry eyes/mouth, and lung problems.

 

Option C. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) reactivation: CMV reactivation is a common complication of allo-SCT, but it typically presents with fever, fatigue, and less specific gastrointestinal symptoms. It doesn't usually cause the characteristic skin rash seen in GVHD.

 

Option D. Engraftment syndrome: This is a non-infectious inflammatory syndrome that can occur shortly after transplant. It may present with fever, rash, and pulmonary edema, but it usually lacks the specific gastrointestinal symptoms of GVHD.

 

Educational objective:

 

Acute GVHD is a serious complication of allo-SCT and requires prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A patient with a history of liver disease receives a massive blood transfusion. Which complication should be monitored closely due to the presence of citrate in transfused blood?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypocalcemia and metabolic alkalosis

 

Option C:

 

Citrate in blood products can chelate calcium, leading to hypocalcemia. Citrate is also metabolized to bicarbonate, potentially causing metabolic alkalosis. These complications are more likely in patients with liver disease due to impaired citrate metabolism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypothermia: Hypothermia can be a complication of massive transfusion, but it's primarily caused by the rapid infusion of cold blood products, not the citrate preservative.

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: While hyperkalemia can occur during massive transfusion, it's usually due to the breakdown of red blood cells releasing potassium, not the citrate itself.

 

Option D. Thrombocytopenia: Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) can occur due to dilution from massive transfusion or consumption of platelets in trauma or sepsis. It's not directly related to citrate.

 

Educational objective:

 

Patients with liver disease are at increased risk for hypocalcemia and metabolic alkalosis following blood transfusion due to impaired citrate metabolism.

questions.text: A patient develops fever, chills, flank pain, and hypotension after starting a red blood cell transfusion. Urine output is significantly reduced, and the urine appears dark. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR)

 

Option D:

 

The classic triad of fever, flank pain, and red/brown urine, along with hypotension and oliguria, strongly suggests AHTR.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR): While FNHTR is the most common transfusion reaction, it typically presents with fever and chills but not hypotension, flank pain, or dark urine.

 

Option B. Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI): TRALI is characterized by acute respiratory distress (e.g., dyspnea, hypoxemia) and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which are not present in this case.

 

Option C. Allergic transfusion reaction: Allergic reactions usually manifest with urticaria (hives), itching, and sometimes bronchospasm. They typically do not cause flank pain, dark urine, or significant hypotension.

 

Educational objective:

 

AHTR is a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate recognition and intervention.

questions.text: A patient with a history of recurrent allergic reactions to blood transfusions presents for a scheduled surgery. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to assess their risk of anaphylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum IgA levels

 

Option B:

 

Recurrent allergic reactions to blood transfusions raise suspicion for IgA deficiency. Measuring serum immunoglobulin levels, particularly IgA, is the most direct way to assess this risk.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Direct antiglobulin test (DAT): The DAT detects antibodies or complement proteins bound to red blood cells. While it is useful in diagnosing certain types of transfusion reactions (like hemolytic reactions), it doesn't directly assess the risk of IgA-mediated anaphylaxis.

 

Option C. HLA antibody screening: HLA antibodies are directed against human leukocyte antigens (HLA) on white blood cells. While these antibodies can cause transfusion reactions, they are not the primary culprit in IgA deficiency-related anaphylaxis.

 

Option D. Platelet aggregation studies: These tests assess platelet function and are primarily used to investigate bleeding disorders. They are not relevant to the diagnosis of IgA deficiency or the assessment of anaphylaxis risk.

 

Educational objective:

 

Serum immunoglobulin levels are essential for diagnosing IgA deficiency in patients with a history of transfusion reactions.

questions.text: A patient develops acute respiratory distress, fever, and hypotension within 2 hours of receiving a blood transfusion. On examination, there was no rise in JVP/pedal edema Chest X-ray reveals bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

 

Option C:

 

The rapid onset of respiratory distress, fever, hypotension, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates following transfusion strongly suggests TRALI.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR): While AHTR can also cause fever and hypotension, it typically presents with additional symptoms like flank pain, hemoglobinuria (dark urine), and signs of hemolysis (increased bilirubin, decreased haptoglobin).

 

Option B. Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO): TACO is characterized by signs of fluid overload, such as hypertension, elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP), and peripheral edema. Patients with TACO may also have respiratory distress due to pulmonary edema, but it is usually not associated with fever or hypotension.

 

Option D. Anaphylactic transfusion reaction: Anaphylactic reactions typically manifest with urticaria (hives), angioedema, and bronchospasm. While hypotension can occur, it is usually accompanied by other allergic symptoms not present in this case.

 

Educational objective:

 

TRALI is a serious complication of transfusion characterized by acute lung injury.

questions.text: A patient develops jaundice, fever, and a gradual drop in hemoglobin levels one week after receiving a blood transfusion. The pre-transfusion antibody screen was negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR)

 

Option D:

 

The onset of symptoms (jaundice, fever, and falling hemoglobin) days after transfusion, combined with a negative pre-transfusion antibody screen, is characteristic of DHTR.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR): AHTR typically presents with rapid onset (within hours) of fever, chills, flank pain, and hemoglobinuria. It is usually caused by ABO incompatibility, which would have been detected in the pre-transfusion testing.

 

Option B. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR): FNHTR is the most common type of transfusion reaction and usually presents with fever and chills within a few hours of transfusion. It is not associated with jaundice or a drop in hemoglobin levels.

 

Option C. Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI): TRALI presents with acute respiratory distress, hypotension, and pulmonary edema shortly after transfusion. It does not typically cause jaundice or a delayed drop in hemoglobin.

 

Educational objective:

 

DHTRs are typically delayed and caused by undetected antibodies against minor blood group antigens.

questions.text: A 78-year-old patient is diagnosed with newly diagnosed AML but has significant comorbidities and is considered unfit for intensive induction chemotherapy ("7+3"). Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypomethylating agent (HMA) + Venetoclax

 

Option C:

 

The image indicates that for patients unfit for intensive chemotherapy, the combination of an HMA (e.g., azacitidine or decitabine) with venetoclax is the preferred treatment option.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Standard "7+3" induction chemotherapy: Standard "7+3" is too intensive for unfit patients.

 

Option B. Midostaurin + Gemtuzumab ozogamicin: Midostaurin and Gemtuzumab are often added to standard induction, not used in isolation for unfit patients.

 

Option D. Allogeneic stem cell transplant: Allogeneic stem cell transplant is a potential curative option but is generally not feasible for older patients with comorbidities.

 

Educational objective:

 

HMA + Venetoclax offers a less intensive, yet effective, treatment option for older or unfit AML patients.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with a rapidly enlarging jaw mass and systemic B symptoms. Biopsy reveals medium-sized lymphoid cells with a starry sky pattern. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is most likely associated with this lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) t(8;14)

 

Option C:

 

The t(8;14) translocation is the hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma. It results in the overexpression of the MYC oncogene, leading to aggressive proliferation of B cells. The other translocations are associated with different lymphomas (A & D: Mantle Cell Lymphoma, B: Follicular Lymphoma).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. t(11;14): This translocation is characteristic of Mantle Cell Lymphoma. It involves the cyclin D1 gene and leads to increased cell cycle progression.

 

Option B. t(14;18): This translocation is associated with Follicular Lymphoma. It involves the BCL2 gene, which inhibits apoptosis and promotes cell survival.

 

Option D. t(11;18): This translocation is also associated with Mantle Cell Lymphoma, like option A.

 

Educational objective:

 

Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell lymphoma characterized by a specific translocation, t(8;14).

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with HIV presents with multiple violet-colored skin lesions and lymphadenopathy. The lesion is shown below. Which of the following is the most common etiological agent for his skin condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)

 

Option A.

 

The presentation is consistent with Kaposi sarcoma (KS), a malignancy strongly associated with HHV-8 infection, particularly in immunocompromised individuals like those with HIV. While EBV can cause lymphoma, it doesn't typically present with skin lesions. HPV is linked to various cancers but not KS. HTLV-1 causes adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma, which has a different presentation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV): While EBV is associated with several malignancies (lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma), it doesn't typically cause the characteristic skin lesions seen in Kaposi sarcoma.

 

Option C. Human papillomavirus (HPV): HPV is primarily associated with cervical cancer and other anogenital cancers. It doesn't cause the type of lesions seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Human T-lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1): HTLV-1 is associated with adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma, a type of blood cancer. It doesn't usually cause the distinctive skin lesions of Kaposi sarcoma.

 

Educational objective:

HHV-8 is the causative agent of Kaposi sarcoma, a malignancy often seen in HIV-infected individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following types of UV radiation is MOST strongly linked to the development of skin cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) UVB

 

Option B.

 

UVB radiation is a type of ultraviolet radiation that has a shorter wavelength than UVA but a longer wavelength than UVC. It is the most damaging type of UV radiation that reaches the Earth's surface. UVB radiation is absorbed by the DNA in skin cells, causing damage that can lead to mutations and the development of skin cancer.  

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. gamma rays: Gamma rays are a type of ionizing radiation with very short wavelengths and high energy. While they are carcinogenic, they are not the primary type of radiation associated with skin cancer.  

 

Option C. x-rays: X-rays are also a type of ionizing radiation with shorter wavelengths than UV radiation. They are used in medical imaging and can also be carcinogenic, but their primary association is not with skin cancer.  

 

Option D. alpha-rays: Alpha rays are a type of particle radiation consisting of two protons and two neutrons. They have low penetrating power and are not associated with skin cancer.

 

Educational objective:

UVB radiation is the most significant contributor to skin cancer development.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, with a history of silicosis presents with progressive dyspnea and pleural plaques on imaging. Which of the following malignancies is he most likely at risk for developing in future?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mesothelioma

 

Option B.

 

  • Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust. It's often found in occupations like mining, quarrying, and sandblasting.
  • Pleural plaques are thickening of the lining of the lungs (pleura) and are a hallmark of asbestos exposure.
  • Asbestos exposure is the primary risk factor for mesothelioma, a rare but aggressive cancer of the pleura.

 

Since the patient has both silicosis and pleural plaques, it strongly suggests a history of asbestos exposure, making mesothelioma the most likely future malignancy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Small cell lung cancer: While smoking is the primary risk factor, it's not directly associated with silicosis or pleural plaques.

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung: Also primarily linked to smoking, not specifically to silicosis or asbestos.

 

Option D. Adenocarcinoma of the lung: The most common type of lung cancer but not directly associated with silicosis or asbestos.

 

Educational objective:

The combination of silicosis and pleural plaques is a strong indicator of asbestos exposure and significantly increases the risk of developing mesothelioma. Early detection and monitoring are crucial for individuals with this history.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of smoking presents with cough, hemoptysis, and a lung mass on chest X-ray. Which of the following tumor markers is MOST likely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NSE

 

Option C.

 

NSE is a marker for neuroendocrine tumors, including small cell lung cancer (SCLC). Its elevation in this scenario, along with the clinical presentation and imaging findings, supports the diagnosis of SCLC. The other markers are not typically associated with SCLC.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. CEA (Carcinoembryonic Antigen): While CEA can be elevated in some lung cancers, it's more commonly associated with colorectal, breast, and other gastrointestinal cancers.

 

Option B. AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein): AFP is primarily used as a marker for liver cancer (hepatocellular carcinoma) and certain germ cell tumors. It's not typically elevated in lung cancers.

 

Option D. CA 19-9 (Carbohydrate Antigen 19-9): CA 19-9 is most commonly used as a marker for pancreatic cancer and some other gastrointestinal malignancies. It's not a primary marker for lung cancers.

 

Educational objective:

NSE is a useful marker for the diagnosis and monitoring of neuroendocrine tumors, particularly SCLC.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a palpable breast mass and nipple discharge. Which tumor marker would be MOST appropriate to order in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CA 15-3

 

Option B.

 

CA 15-3 is a tumor marker used to monitor breast cancer response to treatment and detect recurrence. While the other options are tumor markers, they are not typically used in the initial evaluation of a breast mass.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CA 19-9: This marker is primarily associated with pancreatic cancer and some gastrointestinal malignancies. It's not routinely used in the initial evaluation of breast masses.

 

Option C. CA-125: This marker is primarily associated with ovarian cancer and is not routinely used in the evaluation of breast masses.

 

Option D. CEA: This marker can be elevated in various cancers, including breast cancer. However, it is not specific for breast cancer and is typically used to monitor response to treatment or detect recurrence rather than in the initial diagnosis of a breast mass.

 

Educational objective:

CA 15-3 is a useful marker for monitoring breast cancer progression and treatment response.

choices.text: Annual mammogram starting at age 40

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a known BRCA1 mutation desires the most effective risk reduction strategy for breast cancer. Which of the following options would you recommend?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Risk-reducing bilateral mastectomy (rrBLM)

 

Option B.

 

The image indicates that rrBLM can reduce the risk of breast cancer by ≥ 90% in BRCA1/2 mutation carriers. While rrBSO reduces ovarian cancer risk, it doesn't directly address breast cancer risk. Mammography and chemoprevention are screening and risk reduction strategies, respectively, but not as effective as rrBLM in preventing breast cancer.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (rrBSO): While rrBSO is a risk-reducing surgery, it primarily targets ovarian cancer risk. Although it can somewhat decrease breast cancer risk in premenopausal women, it is not as effective as rrBLM in directly addressing breast cancer.

 

Option C. Annual mammogram starting at age 40: Mammography is a screening tool for early detection, not a preventive measure. In women with BRCA1 mutations, who often develop breast cancer at a younger age, mammography alone may not be sufficient for early detection.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen chemoprevention: While tamoxifen can reduce the risk of breast cancer in women with BRCA2 mutations, its effectiveness is not as high as rrBLM in BRCA1 carriers. Additionally, it comes with potential side effects and is not suitable for all women.

 

Educational objective:

rrBLM is the most effective risk reduction strategy for breast cancer in BRCA1/2 mutation carriers.

questions.text: Which of the following HPV types are covered by BOTH Gardasil and Cervarix vaccines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 16 and 18

 

Option B.

 

Gardasil covers HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18, while Cervarix covers types 16 and 18. Therefore, both vaccines cover types 16 and 18.

 

Educational objective:

HPV types 16 and 18 are high-risk types associated with a majority of cervical cancers, making their inclusion in both vaccines crucial.

choices.text: 10 years before her father's age of diagnosis (i.e., at age 45)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has a father who was diagnosed with colorectal cancer at age 55. When should she initiate screening for colorectal cancer, according to the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 10 years before her father's age of diagnosis (i.e., at age 45)

 

Option D.

 

Individuals with a first-degree relative (FDR) diagnosed with CRC should begin screening 10 years before the earliest diagnosis in the FDR or Age ≥ 40-45. In this case, screening should start at age 45.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Immediately: While having a family history of colorectal cancer (CRC) does increase risk, immediate screening is not recommended unless there are other concerning symptoms or risk factors.

 

Option B. At age 45: This is the general recommended age to begin screening for those with average risk, but with a family history of CRC, earlier screening is appropriate.

 

Option C. At age 50: This is too late for someone with a first-degree relative diagnosed with CRC at age 55. Earlier screening is necessary to detect potential problems early.

 

Educational objective:

Individuals with a family history of colorectal cancer should start screening 10 years younger than the age at which their first-degree relative was diagnosed. This allows for early detection and intervention of precancerous polyps or early-stage cancer, ultimately improving outcomes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with metastatic lung cancer reports fatigue but is still able to perform most of their daily activities, including light housework and grocery shopping. Which ECOG performance status is MOST appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1

 

Option B.

 

The patient can perform normal activities but with some effort due to fatigue. This aligns with ECOG PS 1, where strenuous activity is restricted, but the patient remains fully ambulatory.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

ECOG PS 1 indicates a patient can carry out normal activity with effort, though strenuous activity is limited.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight loss, and splenomegaly. Blood tests reveal an elevated white blood cell count with a predominance of immature myeloid cells. Cytogenetic analysis of the patient's bone marrow cells is most likely to reveal which of the following abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BCR-ABL1 fusion gene

 

Option B:

 

The clinical presentation is suggestive of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of myeloid cells in the bone marrow.

 

  • The BCR-ABL1 fusion gene is the hallmark of CML, resulting from a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (t(9;22)). This fusion gene encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase that drives the uncontrolled cell growth.  

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HER2/ERBB2 amplification is associated with breast and other solid tumors.  

 

Option C. CBFB-MYH11 and FIP1L1-PDGFRA are fusion genes associated with other hematological malignancies.

 

Option D. Polyploidy refers to an increased number of chromosome sets and is not typically seen in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The BCR-ABL1 fusion gene is a specific genetic abnormality that is highly diagnostic for CML and serves as a target for tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy

choices.text: Elevated alkaline phosphatase, normal ALT and AST

questions.text: Which of the following patterns of liver function tests (LFTs) is most consistent with ischemic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elevated ALT and AST

 

Option C:


Ischemic hepatitis, also known as shock liver, typically presents with marked elevations in both ALT and AST levels, often exceeding 10 times the upper limit of normal. This pattern reflects acute hepatocellular injury due to compromised hepatic perfusion.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Elevated ALT, normal AST: While elevated ALT is characteristic of hepatocellular injury, normal AST levels would be less typical in ischemic hepatitis, where both enzymes are usually elevated.
 

Option B. Elevated AST, normal ALT: While elevated AST can indicate hepatocellular injury, normal ALT levels would be less consistent with ischemic hepatitis.
 

Option D. Elevated alkaline phosphatase, normal ALT and AST: This pattern is more suggestive of cholestatic liver disease rather than ischemic hepatitis, as alkaline phosphatase levels are typically elevated in cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:


Ischemic hepatitis typically presents with marked elevations in both ALT and AST levels, reflecting acute hepatocellular injury due to compromised hepatic perfusion.

choices.text: Elevated alkaline phosphatase, normal ALT and AST

questions.text: Which of the following patterns of liver function tests (LFTs) is most consistent with acute fulminant Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elevated ALT and AST

 

Option C:


In acute fulminant Wilson's disease, both ALT and AST levels are typically elevated, reflecting severe hepatocellular injury and necrosis. This pattern of LFT abnormalities is consistent with acute liver failure in the setting of Wilson's disease.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Elevated ALT, normal AST: While elevated ALT is characteristic of hepatocellular injury, normal AST levels would be less typical in acute fulminant Wilson's disease, where both enzymes are usually elevated.
 

Option B. Elevated AST, normal ALT: While elevated AST can indicate hepatocellular injury, normal ALT levels would be less consistent with acute fulminant Wilson's disease.
 

Option D. Elevated alkaline phosphatase, normal ALT and AST: This pattern is more suggestive of cholestatic liver disease rather than acute fulminant Wilson's disease, as alkaline phosphatase levels are typically elevated in cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:


Acute fulminant Wilson's disease presents with markedly elevated ALT and AST levels, reflecting severe hepatocellular injury and necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following calculations is most appropriate to assess the severity and prognosis of alcoholic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maddrey's Discriminant Function

 

Option C:


Maddrey's Discriminant Function is calculated using the formula: (4.6 × [prothrombin time (seconds) - control]) + serum bilirubin (mg/dL). A value greater than 32 indicates severe alcoholic hepatitis and predicts mortality.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Child-Pugh score: While used to assess the severity of liver disease, the Child-Pugh score may not be as specific for alcoholic hepatitis severity as Maddrey's Discriminant Function.
 

Option B. Glasgow Alcoholic Hepatitis Score: This scoring system assesses the severity of alcoholic hepatitis but does not specifically incorporate INR, which is a component of Maddrey's Discriminant Function.
 

Option D. MELD score: The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score is used for liver transplant allocation and does not specifically assess the severity of alcoholic hepatitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Maddrey's Discriminant Function is a valuable tool for assessing the severity and prognosis of alcoholic hepatitis, guiding treatment decisions and predicting mortality in patients with this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following histological findings is characteristic of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presence of Mallory-Denk bodies

 

Option A:


Mallory-Denk bodies, which are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes, are characteristic histological features of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), indicating cellular injury and necrosis.

 

Explanation:


Option B. Periportal inflammation: While inflammation is a feature of NASH, it typically involves the lobular region rather than periportal areas.
 

Option C. Bile duct proliferation: Bile duct proliferation is not a typical histological finding in NASH and is more suggestive of chronic cholestatic liver diseases.
 

Option D. Hepatic iron deposition: Hepatic iron deposition is not a characteristic histological finding in NASH and is more commonly associated with hereditary hemochromatosis or chronic liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:


Characteristic histological features of NASH, such as Mallory-Denk bodies, helps in the accurate diagnosis and differentiation from other liver diseases, guiding appropriate management strategies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman reports chronic diarrhea, bloating, fatigue, and unexplained weight loss, worsened by consuming gluten-containing foods. She has iron-deficiency anemia and low vitamin D levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Celiac Disease

 

Option C:

 

The patient's symptoms of diarrhea, bloating, and weight loss, particularly worsening after consuming gluten-containing foods (pasta, bread), along with iron-deficiency anemia and low vitamin D levels (indicating malabsorption), are highly suggestive of celiac disease. Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing malabsorption and a range of gastrointestinal and extraintestinal symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS): While IBS can cause similar gastrointestinal symptoms, it does not lead to nutrient malabsorption or the specific nutrient deficiencies seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD): IBD, including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, could cause similar symptoms and anemia, but the specific worsening with gluten-containing foods and the combination of deficiencies point more towards celiac disease.

 

Option D. Gastric Ulcer: A gastric ulcer might cause pain and anemia due to bleeding, but it would not typically cause the nutrient malabsorption, diarrhea, and specific dietary trigger related to gluten intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic gastrointestinal symptoms that worsen with gluten ingestion, combined with iron-deficiency anemia and other signs of malabsorption, are suggestive of celiac disease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with intermittent episodes of mild jaundice, particularly during periods of stress or fasting. Laboratory tests reveal unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia with normal liver function tests. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gilbert Syndrome

 

Option C:


Gilbert Syndrome is characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1), resulting in impaired bilirubin conjugation. Patients typically have normal liver function tests and may experience exacerbations of jaundice during periods of stress, fasting, or illness.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Wilson's disease: Wilson's disease presents with hepatic copper accumulation leading to liver dysfunction, neurological symptoms, and Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are not present in Gilbert Syndrome.
 

Option B. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to increased bilirubin production from hemolysis, but it is associated with abnormal liver function tests reflecting increased bilirubin turnover.
 

Option D. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to impaired bilirubin excretion into bile, resulting in darkly pigmented liver tissue, which is not seen in Gilbert Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


The clinical presentation and laboratory findings of Gilbert Syndrome, includes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia with normal liver function tests.

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate presents with severe jaundice since birth. Laboratory tests reveal markedly elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels without evidence of hemolysis or liver dysfunction. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crigler-Najjar Syndrome

 

Option C:


Crigler-Najjar Syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by deficient activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1), leading to impaired bilirubin conjugation. This results in severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia without hemolysis or liver dysfunction. Crigler-Najjar Syndrome is divided into type 1, which is more severe and requires lifelong phototherapy or liver transplantation, and type 2, which is less severe.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Gilbert Syndrome: Gilbert Syndrome also presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia but is milder and typically presents later in life.


Option B. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, but it is associated with evidence of hemolysis on laboratory tests, which is not present in Crigler-Najjar Syndrome.


Option D. Dubin-Johnson Syndrome: Dubin-Johnson Syndrome presents with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and is characterized by darkly pigmented liver tissue, which is not seen in Crigler-Najjar Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


The clinical presentation and laboratory findings of Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, includes severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia without evidence of hemolysis or liver dysfunction, is essential for early diagnosis and appropriate management, which may include phototherapy or liver transplantation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with chronic jaundice and dark-colored urine. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of conjugated bilirubin and normal liver function tests. Abdominal imaging shows a liver with a characteristic "black liver" appearance. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dubin-Johnson Syndrome

 

Option D:


Dubin-Johnson Syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defective hepatobiliary transport protein (MRP2) leading to impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile. This results in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia without liver dysfunction, giving the liver a characteristic black appearance on imaging due to pigment deposition

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Gilbert Syndrome: Gilbert Syndrome presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1), without evidence of liver dysfunction or bile pigment deposition.
 

Option B. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to increased bilirubin production from hemolysis, but it is not associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or liver pigment deposition.
 

Option C. Crigler-Najjar Syndrome: Crigler-Najjar Syndrome is characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to deficient activity of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1), without evidence of liver pigment deposition.

 

Educational Objective:


The clinical presentation and characteristic imaging findings of Dubin-Johnson Syndrome, including conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and a "black liver" appearance, aids in accurate diagnosis and differentiation from other causes of jaundice.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with persistent jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and failure to thrive. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of conjugated bilirubin and liver function tests consistent with cholestasis. Abdominal imaging shows no abnormalities. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis (PFIC)

 

Option D:


PFIC is a group of rare genetic disorders characterized by impaired bile flow due to defects in hepatobiliary transport proteins, leading to cholestasis. Infants typically present with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and failure to thrive, along with elevated conjugated bilirubin levels and normal or mildly abnormal liver function tests. Imaging studies may appear normal initially.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Wilson's disease: Wilson's disease presents with hepatic copper accumulation leading to liver dysfunction and neurological symptoms, which are not typical features of PFIC.
 

Option B. Alagille syndrome: Alagille syndrome presents with bile duct paucity, characteristic facial features, and cardiac abnormalities, which are not features of PFIC.
 

Option C. Crigler-Najjar syndrome: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to deficient activity of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1), which is different from the cholestatic presentation seen in PFIC.

 

Educational Objective:


The clinical presentation and laboratory findings of progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis (PFIC), includes cholestasis with elevated conjugated bilirubin levels and normal or mildly abnormal liver function tests.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a patient's hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection status if he has positive serology for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) , who has come for a routine check up ?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic hepatitis B infection

 

Option A:


Positive HBsAg indicates active hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. In the absence of seroconversion within six months, it is classified as chronic hepatitis B infection.

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Acute hepatitis B infection: Acute infection is characterized by the presence of HBsAg along with other markers such as IgM anti-HBc and HBV DNA.
 

Option C. Immune control phase: Immune control phase is characterized by low viral load, normal liver enzymes, and negative HBeAg.
 

Option D. Resolved hepatitis B infection: Resolved infection is characterized by the presence of anti-HBs and absence of HBsAg.

 

Educational Objective:


HBsAg positivity indicates chronic hepatitis B infection that helps in appropriate management and monitoring of patients.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male with a history of dyspepsia is referred to gastroenterology for evaluation. What is the most appropriate initial test for Helicobacter pylori in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urea breath test

 

The urea breath test is a non-invasive, sensitive, and specific test used for the initial diagnosis of Helicobacter pylori infection, particularly in patients with uninvestigated dyspepsia without alarming features. It is convenient and provides quick results, making it appropriate for this patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Serologic antibody test: This test can indicate past or present infection but cannot distinguish between the two, making it less useful for initial diagnosis or confirmation of eradication.

 

Option C. Stool antigen test: Although this test is also non-invasive and has good sensitivity and specificity, the urea breath test is generally preferred due to its rapidity and convenience.

 

Option D. Endoscopic biopsy for histology: While accurate, endoscopy is invasive and not recommended as an initial test for patients without alarm symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For initial testing of Helicobacter pylori in patients with dyspepsia and no alarming features, the non-invasive and accurate urea breath test is the most appropriate choice.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic hepatitis B infection presents with elevated liver enzymes and detectable HBV DNA levels. The patient has no evidence of cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment according to current guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF)

 

Option C:


Current guidelines recommend nucleos(t)ide analogs such as tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) or entecavir as the first-line treatment for chronic hepatitis B infection due to their potent antiviral activity and low rates of resistance development.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Lamivudine: Lamivudine is an older nucleoside analog and is associated with high rates of resistance, making it a less preferred option for initial treatment.
 

Option B. Interferon-alpha: Interferon-alpha is less commonly used due to its side effect profile and limited efficacy compared to nucleos(t)ide analogs.
 

Option D. Adefovir dipivoxil: Adefovir dipivoxil is another nucleotide analog, but it is associated with a higher rate of nephrotoxicity and resistance compared to TDF or entecavir.

 

Educational Objective:


The current treatment guidelines for chronic hepatitis B infection, includes the preference for nucleos(t)ide analogs such as tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) or entecavir as initial therapy that aids in appropriate management and prevention of disease progression.

questions.text: Which of the following are confirmatory tests for active HCV infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HCV RNA PCR

 

Option A:


HCV RNA PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) testing is the confirmatory test of choice to detect active HCV infection. It directly measures the presence of HCV RNA in the blood, indicating that the virus is currently replicating. This test is used to confirm active infection in patients who have tested positive for anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The HCV core antigen assay can be used as an alternative to HCV RNA PCR in some cases to confirm active infection, but HCV RNA PCR remains the gold standard for confirming active HCV replication.

 

Option C. HCV genotyping is important for determining the genotype of the HCV virus, which can influence treatment decisions. However, it is not the initial confirmatory test for active infection; it is typically done after confirming active infection with HCV RNA PCR.

 

Option D. Liver biopsy is an invasive procedure used to assess liver damage and is not used as a confirmatory test for active HCV infection. It may be used in certain clinical scenarios to assess the extent of liver fibrosis or cirrhosis but is not necessary for the initial diagnosis of HCV.

 

Educational Objective:


HCV RNA PCR is the confirmatory test for active infection following positive anti-HCV antibody serology that aids in accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

choices.text: Anti-HCV antibodies indicate active HCV infection
HCV RNA PCR is not necessary if anti-HCV antibodies are positive
Resolved HCV infection is characterized by positive HCV RNA PCR
HCV core antigen assay is used to detect prior HCV exposure

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents tests positive for anti-HCV antibodies and elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following statements regarding HCV serology is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HCV core antigen assay is used to detect prior HCV exposure

 

Option D:


The HCV core antigen assay detects the presence of HCV core protein in the blood and is used as an alternative to anti-HCV antibody testing for detecting prior HCV exposure. Positive anti-HCV antibodies indicate past or current HCV infection but do not distinguish between resolved and chronic infection. HCV RNA PCR is necessary to confirm active infection.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Anti-HCV antibodies indicate exposure to the HCV virus but do not differentiate between active and resolved infections. The presence of antibodies alone cannot confirm active HCV infection.

 

Option B. HCV RNA PCR testing is necessary to confirm active HCV infection even if anti-HCV antibodies are positive. This is because anti-HCV antibodies can be present in both active and resolved infections.

 

Option C. Resolved HCV infection is characterized by the presence of anti-HCV antibodies without detectable HCV RNA. The absence of HCV RNA indicates that the virus is not currently replicating in the patient's body.

 

Educational Objective:


HCV core antigen assay helps to detect prior HCV exposure, that aids in accurate diagnosis and management of hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection.

choices.text: Sofosbuvir and ribavirin for 24 weeks

questions.text: For a 55-year-old female with chronic HCV infection genotype 2, without cirrhosis, what is the most appropriate treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sofosbuvir/Velpatasvir for 12 weeks

 

Option B:

 

For patients with HCV genotype 2 infection without cirrhosis, the recommended treatment regimen is sofosbuvir/velpatasvir for 12 weeks. This combination therapy has shown high efficacy across various HCV genotypes, including genotype 2, and is well-tolerated by patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ledipasvir/sofosbuvir is highly effective in treating HCV genotype 1 infections but is not the first choice for genotype 2.

 

Option C. Elbasvir/grazoprevir is primarily used for HCV genotype 1 and 4 infections, and thus not the optimal choice for genotype 2.

 

Option D. Sofosbuvir and ribavirin for 24 weeks is an older regimen that may be considered in certain contexts for genotype 2 but is less preferable due to the longer treatment duration and side effects associated with ribavirin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The efficacy of sofosbuvir/velpatasvir for 12 weeks helps  in treating HCV genotype 2 infections.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal discomfort for the past few weeks. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes, hypergammaglobulinemia, and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA). What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autoimmune hepatitis

 

Option C:


The presentation of fatigue, jaundice, elevated liver enzymes, hypergammaglobulinemia, and positive autoantibodies (ANA and ASMA) is highly suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis. This chronic inflammatory liver disease is characterized by immune-mediated hepatocellular injury.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Alcoholic hepatitis: While alcoholic hepatitis can present with similar symptoms, it is typically associated with a history of excessive alcohol consumption and may not have the characteristic autoantibodies seen in autoimmune hepatitis.
 

Option B. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD): NAFLD typically presents with elevated liver enzymes and fatty infiltration of the liver but lacks the characteristic autoimmune serological markers seen in autoimmune hepatitis.
 

Option D. Primary biliary cholangitis: Primary biliary cholangitis may present with similar symptoms, but it is characterized by the presence of anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA) and histological features of bile duct damage, which are not seen in autoimmune hepatitis.

 

Educational Objective:


The clinical presentation and laboratory findings of autoimmune hepatitis, includes elevated liver enzymes, hypergammaglobulinemia, and positive autoantibodies (ANA and ASMA).

choices.text: Metronidazole, tetracycline, bismuth subsalicylate, and omeprazole

questions.text: What is the most appropriate initial treatment regimen for H. pylori infection in a patient with no prior antibiotic exposure and no contraindications is triple therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clarithromycin, amoxicillin, and omeprazole

 

Option A:

 

The recommended initial treatment for H. pylori infection in a patient with no prior antibiotic exposure and no contraindications is triple therapy consisting of a proton pump inhibitor (such as omeprazole) and two antibiotics (clarithromycin and amoxicillin) for 14 days. This regimen has been shown to be effective in eradicating H. pylori and healing peptic ulcers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Metronidazole, tetracycline, bismuth subsalicylate, and omeprazole: This quadruple therapy is an alternative, particularly in areas of high clarithromycin resistance or for patients with previous macrolide exposure.

 

Option C. Amoxicillin, ciprofloxacin, and ranitidine: This combination is not a standard regimen for H. pylori eradication and includes a fluoroquinolone and an H2 blocker, which is less effective than a proton pump inhibitor in this setting.

 

Option D. Metronidazole, ciprofloxacin, and lansoprazole: This regimen does not follow the recommended guidelines for H. pylori treatment due to the inclusion of ciprofloxacin, which is not a first-line agent for this infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial treatment for H. pylori infection should consist of triple therapy with a proton pump inhibitor (like omeprazole) and two antibiotics (clarithromycin and amoxicillin) for 14 days to effectively eradicate the infection and promote ulcer healing.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with fatigue, pruritus, and right upper quadrant abdominal pain. Laboratory tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase and positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA). Abdominal imaging reveals hepatomegaly and features suggestive of intrahepatic cholestasis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

 

Option B:


The clinical presentation of fatigue, pruritus, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase, positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA), and features of intrahepatic cholestasis on imaging is characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC).

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Alcoholic liver disease: Alcoholic liver disease typically presents with a history of alcohol abuse and may have elevated liver enzymes but lacks the characteristic AMA positivity seen in PBC.
 

Option C. Autoimmune hepatitis: Autoimmune hepatitis may present with similar symptoms but is characterized by elevated transaminases and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA), rather than AMA.
 

Option D. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD): NAFLD typically presents with features of metabolic syndrome and may have elevated liver enzymes, but it does not typically present with pruritus or positive AMA.

 

Educational Objective:


The clinical presentation and laboratory findings of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), includes pruritus, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. Laboratory tests reveal elevated alkaline phosphatase and serum bilirubin levels. Imaging studies show multifocal strictures and dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)

 

Option B:


The presentation of fatigue, pruritus, jaundice, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and imaging findings of multifocal strictures and dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts is most consistent with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). PSC is a chronic, progressive liver disease characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts, leading to bile duct strictures that can cause symptoms like jaundice and pruritus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alcoholic liver disease typically presents with a history of significant alcohol consumption and can lead to a spectrum of liver abnormalities, including steatosis, alcoholic hepatitis, and cirrhosis, but it does not typically present with the specific bile duct changes seen in PSC.

 

Option C. Autoimmune hepatitis is characterized by inflammation of the liver due to an autoimmune response and is often associated with elevated transaminases and positive autoimmune markers, which are not the primary findings in this case.

 

Option D. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with metabolic risk factors such as obesity, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia and primarily affects the liver parenchyma, leading to steatosis and potentially steatohepatitis, but it does not cause the bile duct abnormalities seen in PSC.

 

Educational Objective:


The clinical presentation of fatigue, pruritus, jaundice, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and serum bilirubin levels, along with characteristic imaging findings of multifocal strictures and dilatations of bile ducts, is typical of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC).

questions.text: What histopathological feature is characteristic of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) ?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Onion-skinning

 

Option D:


Onion-skinning, which refers to the concentric layers of fibrosis surrounding bile ducts, is a characteristic histopathological feature of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). This feature represents the progressive fibrosis that narrows the bile ducts, leading to their strictures and the clinical manifestations of PSC.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Steatosis, or the accumulation of fat within liver cells, is a feature more commonly associated with conditions like non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and alcoholic liver disease, not PSC.

 

Option B. Mallory-Denk bodies are cytoplasmic inclusions found in liver cells, typically associated with alcoholic liver disease and not characteristic of PSC.

 

Option C. Granulomas are aggregates of macrophages and are more typically associated with conditions such as sarcoidosis or granulomatous hepatitis, not specifically characteristic of PSC.

 

Educational Objective:


Onion-skinning, characterized by concentric fibrosis and inflammation around bile ducts, is a characteristic histopathological feature of primary sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: What scoring system is commonly used for the initial assessment and diagnosis of Wilson Disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nazer Score

 

Option C:

 

The Nazer Score is a scoring system specifically designed for the initial assessment and diagnosis of Wilson Disease. It takes into account various clinical, biochemical, and histological parameters, including neurological symptoms, Kayser-Fleischer rings, serum ceruloplasmin, liver histology, and urinary copper excretion, to help in the diagnosis of Wilson Disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Child-Pugh Score is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis, and to determine the required strength of treatment and the need for liver transplantation.

 

Option B. The MELD Score (Model for End-Stage Liver Disease) is used to prioritize patients for liver transplantation, based on the severity of chronic liver disease.

 

Option D. Ranson's Criteria are used to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis and predict its outcome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nazer Score is a scoring system used for the initial assessment and diagnosis of Wilson Disease, incorporating clinical, biochemical, and histological parameters relevant to the disease.
